elements.content: Three novel homochiral helical metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), namely [Zn(LTP)2] n (1), [Cd(LTP)2] n (2), and [Ni(LTP)2] n (3) (LTP = l-thioproline), have been synthesized and characterized. X-ray crystallographic analysis shows that all the three complexes consist of homochiral left-handed or right-handed helical chains. Complex 1 exhibits 1-D Zn-carboxyl right-handed helical chains constructed by pentacoordinated Zn2+ ions. Complex 2 shows a 2-D homochiral coordination framework with (4, 4) topology based on Cd-carboxyl right-handed helical chains in which Cd2+ ions are 6-fold coordinated. There are various hydrogen bonds between the adjacent helical chains in 1 and 2 which connect them into 3-D supramolecular networks. Complex 3 also exhibits a 2-D homochiral layer structure with (4, 4) topology containing Ni-carboxyl left-handed helical chains. The luminescence properties of 1 and 2 have been investigated briefly.
elements.clean_text: Three novel homochiral helical metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), namely [Zn(LTP)2] n  (1), [Cd(LTP)2] n  (2), and [Ni(LTP)2] n  (3) (LTP = l-thioproline), have been synthesized and characterized. X-ray crystallographic analysis shows that all the three complexes consist of homochiral left-handed or right-handed helical chains. Complex 1 exhibits 1-D Zn-carboxyl right-handed helical chains constructed by pentacoordinated Zn2+ ions. Complex 2 shows a 2-D homochiral coordination framework with (4, 4) topology based on Cd-carboxyl right-handed helical chains in which Cd2+ ions are 6-fold coordinated. There are various hydrogen bonds between the adjacent helical chains in 1 and 2 which connect them into 3-D supramolecular networks. Complex 3 also exhibits a 2-D homochiral layer structure with (4, 4) topology containing Ni-carboxyl left-handed helical chains. The luminescence properties of 1 and 2 have been investigated briefly.

elements.content: Three novel homochiral helical MOFs have been synthesized through the self-assembly approach of transition metals with l-thioproline. All the complexes consist of homochiral left-handed or right-handed helical chains combining helicity with chirality into one crystal phase. 1 exhibits a 1-D chain structure while 2 and 3 show 2-D layers. Various hydrogen bonds in 1 and 2 connect them into 3-D supramolecular networks.
elements.clean_text: Three novel homochiral helical MOFs have been synthesized through the self-assembly approach of transition metals with l-thioproline. All the complexes consist of homochiral left-handed or right-handed helical chains combining helicity with chirality into one crystal phase. 1 exhibits a 1-D chain structure while 2 and 3 show 2-D layers. Various hydrogen bonds in 1 and 2 connect them into 3-D supramolecular networks.

elements.content: Multifunctional metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have received much attention because of their distinctive structures and applications in numerous fields, such as gas storage, chemical separation, heterogeneous catalysis, and optical, electronic, and magnetic materials. Helical and homochiral structures are universal in nature, and helicity and homochirality are extraordinary properties that are found in our daily life. Helical structures are integral to multifarious biological functions and have been attracting extensive attention in coordination chemistry and materials chemistry. In recent years, chemists all over the word have been making great efforts in order to introduce helicity into artificial systems and various helical complexes have been synthesized successfully. Chirality is the most significant feature of a helix, and left- or right-handed helices are nonidentical mirror images. The continuously increasing demand for materials with the functions of enantioselective catalysis and separation and molecular recognition has promoted comprehensive studies in the field of chiral coordination polymers. Although there have been great achievements in the development of the helical MOFs and homochiral MOFs, respectively, to the best of our knowledge, the homochiral helical MOFs which combine the helicity with chirality into one crystal phase are still not very abundant.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Multifunctional metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have received much attention because of their distinctive structures and applications in numerous fields, such as gas storage, chemical separation, heterogeneous catalysis, and optical, electronic, and magnetic materials. Helical and homochiral structures are universal in nature, and helicity and homochirality are extraordinary properties that are found in our daily life. Helical structures are integral to multifarious biological functions and have been attracting extensive attention in coordination chemistry and materials chemistry. In recent years, chemists all over the word have been making great efforts in order to introduce helicity into artificial systems and various helical complexes have been synthesized successfully. Chirality is the most significant feature of a helix, and left- or right-handed helices are nonidentical mirror images. The continuously increasing demand for materials with the functions of enantioselective catalysis and separation and molecular recognition has promoted comprehensive studies in the field of chiral coordination polymers. Although there have been great achievements in the development of the helical MOFs and homochiral MOFs, respectively, to the best of our knowledge, the homochiral helical MOFs which combine the helicity with chirality into one crystal phase are still not very abundant.

elements.content: In order to construct homochiral helical MOFs, we choose l-thioproline (LTP) as ligand. LTP is a sulfur-containing amino acid, and it proves to be an effective antineoplastic drug and adjunctive therapeutic drug with great importance. In the 1980s, there was already research about LTP complexes, and some of them were 0-D or 1-D structures. However, there were few multidimensional helical MOFs reported. The reasons why we choose LTP as ligand to construct homochiral helical MOFs are that, for one thing, using amino acid as ligand, we may probably introduce the chirality to the MOFs, and moreover, making research of the interaction between transition metals and amino acid can provide a theoretical foundation for investigating the metabolism of the transition metals in an organism; for another, the five-membered ring of LTP is not coplanar, and the whole molecule structure of LTP is considerably twisted. Thus, the special distortion conformation of the ligand may offer more opportunity to translate chirality from one metal center to others, forming a helical structure.
elements.clean_text: In order to construct homochiral helical MOFs, we choose l-thioproline (LTP) as ligand. LTP is a sulfur-containing amino acid, and it proves to be an effective antineoplastic drug and adjunctive therapeutic drug with great importance. In the 1980s, there was already research about LTP complexes, and some of them were 0-D or 1-D structures. However, there were few multidimensional helical MOFs reported. The reasons why we choose LTP as ligand to construct homochiral helical MOFs are that, for one thing, using amino acid as ligand, we may probably introduce the chirality to the MOFs, and moreover, making research of the interaction between transition metals and amino acid can provide a theoretical foundation for investigating the metabolism of the transition metals in an organism; for another, the five-membered ring of LTP is not coplanar, and the whole molecule structure of LTP is considerably twisted. Thus, the special distortion conformation of the ligand may offer more opportunity to translate chirality from one metal center to others, forming a helical structure.

elements.content: In this paper, we have synthesized three novel homochiral helical MOFs, [Zn(LTP)2] n (1), [Cd(LTP)2] n (2), and [Ni(LTP)2] n (3), through the self-assembly process, and all three complexes consist of homochiral left-handed or right-handed helical chains, which combine the helicity with chirality into one crystal phase. By reason of the flexible nature of the chiral ligand LTP, helicity and chirality were introduced to the three complexes successfully. We have characterized the resulting complexes by IR, UV−vis, circular dichroism (CD), powder and single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements, and thermogravimetric analyses (TGA), and we also investigated the luminescence properties of complexes 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text: In this paper, we have synthesized three novel homochiral helical MOFs, [Zn(LTP)2] n  (1), [Cd(LTP)2] n  (2), and [Ni(LTP)2] n  (3), through the self-assembly process, and all three complexes consist of homochiral left-handed or right-handed helical chains, which combine the helicity with chirality into one crystal phase. By reason of the flexible nature of the chiral ligand LTP, helicity and chirality were introduced to the three complexes successfully. We have characterized the resulting complexes by IR, UV-vis, circular dichroism (CD), powder and single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements, and thermogravimetric analyses (TGA), and we also investigated the luminescence properties of complexes 1 and 2.

elements.content: All of the chemicals are commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed with an EA1110 CHNS-0 CE elemental analyzer. The IR (KBr pellet) spectra were recorded (400−4000 cm−1 region) on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a DMAX2500 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. The calculated PXRD patterns were produced using the SHELXTL-XPOW program and single crystal reflection data. All solid-state absorption UV−vis absorption spectra were measured in BaSO4 matrices with a Lambda 20 UV−vis spectrometer (Perkin-Elmer, Inc., USA). The solid-state CD spectra were recorded on a J-800 spectropolarimeter (Jasco, Japan). All fluorescence measurements were carried out on a LS 50B luminescence spectrometer (Perkin-Elmer, Inc., USA). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out in an N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min on a STA449C integration thermal analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Procedures

All of the chemicals are commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed with an EA1110 CHNS-0 CE elemental analyzer. The IR (KBr pellet) spectra were recorded (400-4000 cm-1 region) on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a DMAX2500 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. The calculated PXRD patterns were produced using the SHELXTL-XPOW program and single crystal reflection data. All solid-state absorption UV-vis absorption spectra were measured in BaSO4 matrices with a Lambda 20 UV-vis spectrometer (Perkin-Elmer, Inc., USA). The solid-state CD spectra were recorded on a J-800 spectropolarimeter (Jasco, Japan). All fluorescence measurements were carried out on a LS 50B luminescence spectrometer (Perkin-Elmer, Inc., USA). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out in an N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min on a STA449C integration thermal analyzer.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·4H2O (0.065 g, 0.25 mmol), LTP (0.075 g, 0.56 mmol), C2H5OH (1 mL), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (2 mL) was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 100 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min. Colorless rectangular block crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained. The products were washed with H2O and dried in air (56% yield based on Zn(II)). The as-synthesized material is insoluble in water and common organic solvents. Elem anal. Calcd for C8H12ZnN2S2O4: C, 30.63; H, 3.83; N, 8.93; S, 20.42. Found: C, 30.66; H, 3.78; N, 8.96; S, 20.36.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Zn(LTP)2] n  (1)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.065 g, 0.25 mmol), LTP (0.075 g, 0.56 mmol), C2H5OH (1 mL), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (2 mL) was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 100 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min. Colorless rectangular block crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained. The products were washed with H2O and dried in air (56% yield based on Zn(II)). The as-synthesized material is insoluble in water and common organic solvents. Elem anal. Calcd for C8H12ZnN2S2O4: C, 30.63; H, 3.83; N, 8.93; S, 20.42. Found: C, 30.66; H, 3.78; N, 8.96; S, 20.36.

elements.content: To a solution of Cd(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.067 g, 0.25 mmol) in H2O (4 mL) was added a solution of LTP (0.075 g, 0.56 mmol) in H2O (4 mL) to give a mixed solution. After several days, colorless cubic block crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained by very slow evaporation of the mixed solution. The products were washed with H2O and dried in air (65% yield based on Cd(II)). The as-synthesized material is insoluble in water and common organic solvents. Elem anal. Calcd for C8H12CdN2S2O4: C, 26.64; H, 3.33; N, 6.20; S, 17.76. Found: C, 26.70; H, 3.28; N, 6.20; S, 17.73.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Cd(LTP)2] n  (2)

To a solution of Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (0.067 g, 0.25 mmol) in H2O (4 mL) was added a solution of LTP (0.075 g, 0.56 mmol) in H2O (4 mL) to give a mixed solution. After several days, colorless cubic block crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained by very slow evaporation of the mixed solution. The products were washed with H2O and dried in air (65% yield based on Cd(II)). The as-synthesized material is insoluble in water and common organic solvents. Elem anal. Calcd for C8H12CdN2S2O4: C, 26.64; H, 3.33; N, 6.20; S, 17.76. Found: C, 26.70; H, 3.28; N, 6.20; S, 17.73.

elements.content: A procedure identical with that of 1 was followed to prepare 3, except that Zn(NO3)2·4H2O was replaced by Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.073 g, 0.25 mmol). Green rectangular block crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained. The products were washed with H2O and dried in air (57% yield based on Ni(II)). The as-synthesized material is insoluble in water and common organic solvents. Elem Anal. Calcd for C8H12NiN2S2O4: C, 31.30; H, 3.91; N, 9.13; S, 20.87. Found: C, 31.36; H, 3.97; N, 9.05; S, 20.80.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Ni(LTP)2] n  (3)

A procedure identical with that of 1 was followed to prepare 3, except that Zn(NO3)2⋅4H2O was replaced by Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.073 g, 0.25 mmol). Green rectangular block crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained. The products were washed with H2O and dried in air (57% yield based on Ni(II)). The as-synthesized material is insoluble in water and common organic solvents. Elem Anal. Calcd for C8H12NiN2S2O4: C, 31.30; H, 3.91; N, 9.13; S, 20.87. Found: C, 31.36; H, 3.97; N, 9.05; S, 20.80.

elements.content: Single-crystal XRD data for complexes 1−3 were all collected on a Bruker SMART Apex CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 273 K (for 1 and 3) and 293 K (for 2). The structures were solved using a direct method, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL crystallographic software package (Sheldrick, G. M. SHELXL-97. Program for Crystal Structure Solution and Refinement; University of Göttingen: Göttingen, Germany, 1997). Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all non-H atoms. The Flack parameters of 0.01(3), −0.02(4), and 0.01(5) for 1, 2, and 3, respectively, indicate that the absolute configurations are correct. The crystal data and structure refinement details for 1−3 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1−3 are listed in Tables S1, S2, and S3, respectively. The hydrogen-bonding parameters between the adjacent helical chains for 1 and 2 are listed in Table S4.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

Single-crystal XRD data for complexes 1-3 were all collected on a Bruker SMART Apex CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 273 K (for 1 and 3) and 293 K (for 2). The structures were solved using a direct method, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL crystallographic software package (Sheldrick, G. M. SHELXL-97. Program for Crystal Structure Solution and Refinement; University of Göttingen: Göttingen, Germany, 1997). Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all non-H atoms. The Flack parameters of 0.01(3), -0.02(4), and 0.01(5) for 1, 2, and 3, respectively, indicate that the absolute configurations are correct. The crystal data and structure refinement details for 1-3 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1-3 are listed in  Tables S1, S2, and S3, respectively. The hydrogen-bonding parameters between the adjacent helical chains for 1  and 2 are listed in  Table S4.

R 1 = ∑||F o| − |F c||/∑|F o|; wR 2 = ∑w(F o 2 − F c 2)2/∑[w(F o 2)2]1/2.

A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that 1 crystallizes in the chiral monoclinic space group P21, with one Zn2+ ion and three LTP molecules in the structural unit (Figure a). Every Zn2+ ion is five coordinated with three LTP molecules, showing a distorted trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. One LTP molecule acts as a monodentate O-donor ligand while the other two LTP molecules act as a bidentate ligand in which the N and O atoms coordinate to Zn2+ ion, forming two stable five-membered chelate rings, as shown in Figure a, and this is obviously different from the structure reported in the year 1988, in which only one ligand molecule acts as a bidentate ligand. In the arrangement of the distorted trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry, O2 and O3 atoms occupy the axial positions, and O1, N1, and N2 atoms reside in the equatorial positions. The Zn−O distances are 2.004(3), 2.130(3), and 2.046(3) Å, respectively, while the Zn−N distances are 2.083(3) and 2.059(4) Å. Notably, 1 is an example of MOFs containing pentacoordinated Zn2+ ions by only one ligand type. As shown in Figure b, Zn2+ ions are linked together by LTP to yield a 1-D right-handed helical chain. From Figure c, we can see clearly that the infinite helical chain is formed by Zn2+ ions and the carboxyl of LTP in the b direction with a pitch of 5.718 Å. It is noteworthy that there are various hydrogen bonds between the adjacent helical chains in 1. The adjacent helical chains are interconnected to generate a 2-D homochiral layer structure in the bc plane through the hydrogen bonds of NH···O with distances of 2.856(5) and 3.099(5) Å, respectively (Figure d). These layers are further connected by the hydrogen bonds of CH···S with a distance of 3.538(5) Å to produce a 3-D homochiral supramolecular network as depicted in Figure e.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [Zn(LTP)2] n  (1)

A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that 1 crystallizes in the chiral monoclinic space group P21, with one Zn2+ ion and three LTP molecules in the structural unit (Figure a). Every Zn2+ ion is five coordinated with three LTP molecules, showing a distorted trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. One LTP molecule acts as a monodentate O-donor ligand while the other two LTP molecules act as a bidentate ligand in which the N and O atoms coordinate to Zn2+ ion, forming two stable five-membered chelate rings, as shown in Figure a, and this is obviously different from the structure reported in the year 1988, in which only one ligand molecule acts as a bidentate ligand. In the arrangement of the distorted trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry, O2 and O3 atoms occupy the axial positions, and O1, N1, and N2 atoms reside in the equatorial positions. The Zn-O distances are 2.004(3), 2.130(3), and 2.046(3) Å, respectively, while the Zn-N distances are 2.083(3) and 2.059(4) Å. Notably, 1 is an example of MOFs containing pentacoordinated Zn2+ ions by only one ligand type. As shown in Figure b, Zn2+ ions are linked together by LTP to yield a 1-D right-handed helical chain. From Figure c, we can see clearly that the infinite helical chain is formed by Zn2+ ions and the carboxyl of LTP in the b direction with a pitch of 5.718 Å. It is noteworthy that there are various hydrogen bonds between the adjacent helical chains in 1. The adjacent helical chains are interconnected to generate a 2-D homochiral layer structure in the bc plane through the hydrogen bonds of NH⋅⋅⋅O with distances of 2.856(5) and 3.099(5) Å, respectively (Figure d). These layers are further connected by the hydrogen bonds of CH⋅⋅⋅S with a distance of 3.538(5) Å to produce a 3-D homochiral supramolecular network as depicted in Figure e.

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure of 1. (a) Representation of the coordination environment of the Zn2+ ion in 1. (b) Representation of the 1-D helical structure of 1 along the b-axis. (c) The simplified infinite right-handed helical chain of 1 built from Zn2+ ions and carboxyl. (d) Representation of the 2-D layer structure connected through the hydrogen bonds (cyan dash lines) in the bc plane. (e) Representation of the 3-D supramolecular network connected by the hydrogen bonds (green dash lines). Color code: Zn, pink; O, red; N, blue; S, yellow; C, gray. H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  X-ray crystal structure of 1. (a) Representation of the coordination environment of the Zn2+ ion in 1. (b) Representation of the 1-D helical structure of 1 along the b-axis. (c) The simplified infinite right-handed helical chain of 1 built from Zn2+ ions and carboxyl. (d) Representation of the 2-D layer structure connected through the hydrogen bonds (cyan dash lines) in the bc plane. (e) Representation of the 3-D supramolecular network connected by the hydrogen bonds (green dash lines). Color code: Zn, pink; O, red; N, blue; S, yellow; C, gray. H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that 2 crystallizes in the chiral orthorhombic space group P212121 and there are one Cd2+ ion and four LTP molecules in the structural unit. Every Cd2+ ion is six-coordinated via four O atoms and two N atoms from four ligands, forming a distorted octahedral geometry (Figure a). The Cd−O distances are 2.281(3), 2.303(3), 2.304(3), and 2.247(3) Å, respectively, and the Cd−N distances are 2.500(4) and 2.349(3) Å. For the four LTP ligands, two acts as a monodentate O-donor ligand, while the other two act as a bidentate ligand, employing N and O atoms to coordinate to Cd2+ ion, forming two five-membered chelate rings as shown in Figure a. Along the b direction, every Cd2+ ion is linked by LTP molecules, forming an extended Cd-carboxyl right-handed helical chain with a pitch of 8.954 Å (Figure b). These right-handed helical chains are further linked by the carboxyl of the fourth LTP molecule to produce a 2-D homochiral layer structure in the bc plane (Figure c and d). From the topological view, every Cd2+ ion can be considered as a 4-connected node and LTP molecules as linkers, leading to the homochiral layer structure with (4,4) topology (Figure e). There are also various hydrogen bonds between the adjacent helical chains in 2 as in 1. The hydrogen bonds of CH···O with distances of 3.479(7) and 3.079(7) Å, respectively, might make the 2-D layer framework more stable (Figure c). The 2-D layers are further connected by the hydrogen bonds of NH···S with a distance of 3.494(4) Å to form a 3-D homochiral supramolecular network as shown in Figure f.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Cd(LTP)2] n  (2)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that 2 crystallizes in the chiral orthorhombic space group P212121 and there are one Cd2+ ion and four LTP molecules in the structural unit. Every Cd2+ ion is six-coordinated via four O atoms and two N atoms from four ligands, forming a distorted octahedral geometry (Figure a). The Cd-O distances are 2.281(3), 2.303(3), 2.304(3), and 2.247(3) Å, respectively, and the Cd-N distances are 2.500(4) and 2.349(3) Å. For the four LTP ligands, two acts as a monodentate O-donor ligand, while the other two act as a bidentate ligand, employing N and O atoms to coordinate to Cd2+ ion, forming two five-membered chelate rings as shown in Figure a. Along the b direction, every Cd2+ ion is linked by LTP molecules, forming an extended Cd-carboxyl right-handed helical chain with a pitch of 8.954 Å (Figure b). These right-handed helical chains are further linked by the carboxyl of the fourth LTP molecule to produce a 2-D homochiral layer structure in the bc plane (Figure c and d). From the topological view, every Cd2+ ion can be considered as a 4-connected node and LTP molecules as linkers, leading to the homochiral layer structure with (4,4) topology (Figure e). There are also various hydrogen bonds between the adjacent helical chains in 2 as in 1. The hydrogen bonds of CH⋅⋅⋅O with distances of 3.479(7) and 3.079(7) Å, respectively, might make the 2-D layer framework more stable (Figure c). The 2-D layers are further connected by the hydrogen bonds of NH⋅⋅⋅S with a distance of 3.494(4) Å to form a 3-D homochiral supramolecular network as shown in Figure f.

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure of 2. (a) Representation of the coordination environment of Cd2+ ion in 2. (b) The infinite Cd-carboxyl right-handed helical chain of 2 along the b-axis. (c) Representation of the 2-D homochiral layer structure of 2 in the bc plane (the pink dashed lines represent the hydrogen bonds). (d) The simplified 2-D layer structure of 2. (e) Topological representation of the 2-D layer structure of 2. (f) Representation of the 3-D supramolecular network connected through the hydrogen bonds (cyan dash lines). Color code: Cd, green; O, red; N, blue; S, yellow; C, gray. H atoms are omitted for clarity.

(b) The infinite Cd-carboxyl right-handed helical chain of 2 along the b-axis. (c) Representation of the 2-D homochiral layer structure of 2 in the bc plane (the pink dashed lines represent the hydrogen bonds). (d) The simplified 2-D layer structure of 2. (e) Topological representation of the 2-D layer structure of 2. (f) Representation of the 3-D supramolecular network connected through the hydrogen bonds (cyan dash lines). elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis performed on 3 also indicates a 2-D homochiral coordination framework with (4, 4) topology, such as that of 2. 3 crystallizes in the chiral monoclinic space group P21, and the structural unit consists of one Ni2+ ion and four LTP molecules (Figure a). The Ni2+ ion is six-coordinated by four O atoms and two N atoms from four LTP molecules with distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The Ni−O distances are 2.097(6), 2.067(7), 2.082(8), and 2.044(9) Å, respectively, while the Ni−N distances are 2.116(9) and 2.065(8) Å. Two stable five-membered chelate rings are also generated in 3 by the coordination of Ni2+ ion to the N and O atoms of the two bidentate LTP molecules (Figure a). The Ni2+ ions are linked together by LTP to yield a 1-D Ni-carboxyl left-handed helical chain along the b direction with a pitch of 10.146 Å, which is larger than that of both 1 and 2 (Figure b). These helical chains are further connected by LTP linkers, resulting in the homochiral 2-D layer structure with (4, 4) topology in the ab plane (Figure c−f).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Ni(LTP)2] n  (3)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis performed on 3 also indicates a 2-D homochiral coordination framework with (4, 4) topology, such as that of 2. 3 crystallizes in the chiral monoclinic space group P21, and the structural unit consists of one Ni2+ ion and four LTP molecules (Figure a). The Ni2+ ion is six-coordinated by four O atoms and two N atoms from four LTP molecules with distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The Ni-O distances are 2.097(6), 2.067(7), 2.082(8), and 2.044(9) Å, respectively, while the Ni-N distances are 2.116(9) and 2.065(8) Å. Two stable five-membered chelate rings are also generated in 3 by the coordination of Ni2+ ion to the N and O atoms of the two bidentate LTP molecules (Figure a). The Ni2+ ions are linked together by LTP to yield a 1-D Ni-carboxyl left-handed helical chain along the b direction with a pitch of 10.146 Å, which is larger than that of both 1 and 2 (Figure b). These helical chains are further connected by LTP linkers, resulting in the homochiral 2-D layer structure with (4, 4) topology in the ab plane (Figure c-f).

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure of 3. (a) Representation of the coordination environment of Ni2+ ion in 3. (b) The infinite Ni-carboxyl left-handed helical chain of 3. (c) Representation of the 2-D homochiral layer structure of 3. (d) Polyhedral structure representation of 3. (e) The simplified 2-D homochiral layer structure of 3. (f) Topological representation of the 2-D layer structure of 3. Color code: Ni, cyan; O, red; N, blue; S, yellow; C, gray. H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: It is interesting to note that chirality conversion took place from the left-handed to the right-handed helical mode after the ligands LTP coordinated to the metal ions in 1 and 2. We consider that the coordination of the Zn2+ and Cd2+ ions plays an important role in this conversion of the direction of chirality. Through the comparison of the crystal structures of 1−3, it seems that different kinds of metal ions and their coordination numbers strongly influence the structures of 1−3. As the same one subgroup elements, Cd2+, the radius of which is larger than Zn2+, may be easier to coordinate to more organic ligands, so that the coordination numbers of Cd2+ are larger than those of Zn2+, which we think is one of the important factors why 1 displays 1-D helical chains while 2 forms a 2-D coordination framework. The common coordination number of Ni2+ is six, which is also lager than that of Zn2+, so 3 also displays a 2-D covalent layer structure.
elements.clean_text: It is interesting to note that chirality conversion took place from the left-handed to the right-handed helical mode after the ligands LTP coordinated to the metal ions in 1 and 2. We consider that the coordination of the Zn2+ and Cd2+ ions plays an important role in this conversion of the direction of chirality. Through the comparison of the crystal structures of 1-3, it seems that different kinds of metal ions and their coordination numbers strongly influence the structures of 1-3. As the same one subgroup elements, Cd2+, the radius of which is larger than Zn2+, may be easier to coordinate to more organic ligands, so that the coordination numbers of Cd2+ are larger than those of Zn2+, which we think is one of the important factors why 1 displays 1-D helical chains while 2 forms a 2-D coordination framework. The common coordination number of Ni2+ is six, which is also lager than that of Zn2+, so 3 also displays a 2-D covalent layer structure.

elements.content: There are four characteristic absorption bands observed for LTP: the stretching vibration νN−H at 3050 cm−1, the bending vibration δN−H at 1630 cm−1, and the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations, νs COO− at 1432 cm−1 and νas COO− at 1553 cm−1 (, Figure S1). The three complexes exhibit similar IR absorptions (, Figures S2, S3, and S4). Changes of the four characteristic absorption bands occurred after the complexes formation. Accordingly, it can be concluded that the N-atom of the imine group and the O-atom of the carboxyl in LTP are in coordination with the metal ions, resulting in three novel complexes.
elements.clean_text:
IR and Thermogravimetric Analysis

There are four characteristic absorption bands observed for LTP: the stretching vibration νN-H at 3050 cm-1, the bending vibration δN-H at 1630 cm-1, and the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations, νs COO- at 1432 cm-1 and νas COO- at 1553 cm-1 (, Figure S1). The three complexes exhibit similar IR absorptions (, Figures S2, S3, and S4). Changes of the four characteristic absorption bands occurred after the complexes formation. Accordingly, it can be concluded that the N-atom of the imine group and the O-atom of the carboxyl in LTP are in coordination with the metal ions, resulting in three novel complexes.

elements.content: In order to estimate the stability of the frameworks, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1−3 was carried out in nitrogen atmosphere from 30 to 600 °C (, Figures S6, S7, and S8). Complexes 1−3 show similar thermal behaviors. For complexes 1 and 2, no weight loss is observed until it reached 210 and 190 °C, respectively, at which the decomposition of complexes occurred. The TGA curve of 3 shows the framework was not decomposed quickly until 220 °C. All the above suggests that the frameworks of 1−3 are all thermally stable under about 200 °C.
elements.clean_text: In order to estimate the stability of the frameworks, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1-3 was carried out in nitrogen atmosphere from 30 to 600 °C (, Figures S6, S7, and S8). Complexes 1-3 show similar thermal behaviors. For complexes 1 and 2, no weight loss is observed until it reached 210 and 190 °C, respectively, at which the decomposition of complexes occurred. The TGA curve of 3 shows the framework was not decomposed quickly until 220 °C. All the above suggests that the frameworks of 1-3 are all thermally stable under about 200 °C.

elements.content: As the three as-synthesized complexes are all insoluble in water and common organic solvents, in order to examine the chiroptical activities, the circular dichroism (CD) spectra of the ligand LTP and complexes 1−3 were investigated in the solid state (Figure ). The CD spectra of 1−3 obviously indicate they all have chirality and the metal centers are also chiral. The homochiral LTP molecule induced the stereoselective synthesis reaction of the coordination polymers 1−3, and the chirality was transferred from the ligand to the polymers successfully. The formation of the chiral structure of 1−3 has a considerably great influence on the direction (+ or −) of the CD signals except for a slight shift of the absorption peak position compared with that of a LTP molecule, which indicates the CD chromophore mostly comes from the ligand LTP.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Circular Dichroism (CD) Studies

As the three as-synthesized complexes are all insoluble in water and common organic solvents, in order to examine the chiroptical activities, the circular dichroism (CD) spectra of the ligand LTP and complexes 1-3 were investigated in the solid state (Figure ). The CD spectra of 1-3 obviously indicate they all have chirality and the metal centers are also chiral. The homochiral LTP molecule induced the stereoselective synthesis reaction of the coordination polymers 1-3, and the chirality was transferred from the ligand to the polymers successfully. The formation of the chiral structure of 1-3 has a considerably great influence on the direction (+ or -) of the CD signals except for a slight shift of the absorption peak position compared with that of a LTP molecule, which indicates the CD chromophore mostly comes from the ligand LTP.

elements.content: Solid state CD spectra of LTP (black line), 1 (red line), 2 (green line), and 3 (blue line) in KBr.
elements.clean_text: 4  Solid state CD spectra of LTP (black line), 1 (red line), 2 (green line), and 3 (blue line) in KBr.

elements.content: The luminescence properties of LTP, 1, and 2 were investigated in the solid state at room temperature as shown in Figure . For the free LTP ligand, it shows a blue fluorescent emission peak at 398 nm (excitation at 325 nm), and both 1 and 2 also exhibit a blue fluorescent emission peak at 458 and 452 nm (excitation at 370 nm), respectively, with a significant red-shift compared to LTP. It is well-known that both Zn2+ and Cd2+ ions are difficult to be oxidized or reduced, owing to their stable d10 configurations. As a result, the observed emissions of 1 and 2 can probably be attributed to the intraligand fluorescent emission of LTP, which is modified by metal coordination. The chelation of LTP molecules coordinated to metal ions, especially the formation of the stable chelate rings, which can effectively increase the rigidity and the delocalization of electrons of the LTP ligand, thereby reducing the energy loss of thermal vibration, is beneficial to fluorescent emission and results in a red-shift compared to the case of LTP. Both 1 and 2 may be suitable as excellent candidates of blue fluorescent materials.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties of 1 and 2 

The luminescence properties of LTP, 1, and 2 were investigated in the solid state at room temperature as shown in Figure . For the free LTP ligand, it shows a blue fluorescent emission peak at 398 nm (excitation at 325 nm), and both 1 and 2 also exhibit a blue fluorescent emission peak at 458 and 452 nm (excitation at 370 nm), respectively, with a significant red-shift compared to LTP. It is well-known that both Zn2+ and Cd2+ ions are difficult to be oxidized or reduced, owing to their stable d10 configurations. As a result, the observed emissions of 1 and 2 can probably be attributed to the intraligand fluorescent emission of LTP, which is modified by metal coordination. The chelation of LTP molecules coordinated to metal ions, especially the formation of the stable chelate rings, which can effectively increase the rigidity and the delocalization of electrons of the LTP ligand, thereby reducing the energy loss of thermal vibration, is beneficial to fluorescent emission and results in a red-shift compared to the case of LTP. Both 1 and 2 may be suitable as excellent candidates of blue fluorescent materials.

elements.content: Solid state emission spectra of LTP (black), 1 (red), and 2 (green) at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 5  Solid state emission spectra of LTP (black), 1 (red), and 2 (green) at room temperature.

elements.content: We have demonstrated here three novel homochiral helical MOFs, [Zn(LTP)2] n (1), [Cd(LTP)2] n (2), and [Ni(LTP)2] n (3), successfully prepared through the self-assembly approach of transition metals with a chiral amino acid ligand, l-thioproline, which combine the helicity with chirality into one crystal phase. All the three complexes consist of homochiral left-handed or right-handed helical chains. 1 shows 1-D homochiral Zn-carboxyl right-handed helical chains containing pentacoordinated Zn2+ ions. 2 exhibits a 2-D homochiral coordination framework with (4, 4) topology built from the Cd-carboxyl right-handed helical chains in which Cd2+ ions have a 6-fold coordination. Various hydrogen bonds between the adjacent helical chains in 1 and 2 connect them into 3-D supramolecular networks. 3 also exhibits a 2-D homochiral layer structure with (4, 4) topology containing Ni-carboxyl left-handed helical chains. Both 1 and 2 exhibit a blue fluorescent emission peak at 458 and 452 nm (excitation at 370 nm), respectively. The successful syntheses of these new complexes provide novel examples of homochiral helical MOFs combining the helicity with chirality. What is more important, they prove that the chiral ligands with flexible nature and special distortion conformation are more suitable to translate chirality from one metal center to others and form helical species, thereby constructing homochiral helical MOFs successfully. Our further efforts to design and synthesize more new functional homochiral helical materials are underway.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have demonstrated here three novel homochiral helical MOFs, [Zn(LTP)2] n  (1), [Cd(LTP)2] n  (2), and [Ni(LTP)2] n  (3), successfully prepared through the self-assembly approach of transition metals with a chiral amino acid ligand, l-thioproline, which combine the helicity with chirality into one crystal phase. All the three complexes consist of homochiral left-handed or right-handed helical chains. 1 shows 1-D homochiral Zn-carboxyl right-handed helical chains containing pentacoordinated Zn2+ ions. 2 exhibits a 2-D homochiral coordination framework with (4, 4) topology built from the Cd-carboxyl right-handed helical chains in which Cd2+ ions have a 6-fold coordination. Various hydrogen bonds between the adjacent helical chains in 1 and 2 connect them into 3-D supramolecular networks. 3 also exhibits a 2-D homochiral layer structure with (4, 4) topology containing Ni-carboxyl left-handed helical chains. Both 1 and 2 exhibit a blue fluorescent emission peak at 458 and 452 nm (excitation at 370 nm), respectively. The successful syntheses of these new complexes provide novel examples of homochiral helical MOFs combining the helicity with chirality. What is more important, they prove that the chiral ligands with flexible nature and special distortion conformation are more suitable to translate chirality from one metal center to others and form helical species, thereby constructing homochiral helical MOFs successfully. Our further efforts to design and synthesize more new functional homochiral helical materials are underway.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic files for 1−3 in CIF format and selected bond lengths and angles for 1−3, hydrogen-bonding parameters for 1 and 2, IR spectra, UV−vis spectra, TGA, and PXRD patterns for 1−3 in PDF format. This information is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: X-ray crystallographic files for 1-3 in CIF format and selected bond lengths and angles for 1-3, hydrogen-bonding parameters for 1 and 2, IR spectra, UV-vis spectra, TGA, and PXRD patterns for 1-3 in PDF format. This information is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·4H2O (0.065 g, 0.25 mmol), LTP (0.075 g, 0.56 mmol), C2H5OH (1 mL), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (2 mL) was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 100 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min. Colorless rectangular block crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained. The products were washed with H2O and dried in air (56% yield based on Zn(II)). The as-synthesized material is insoluble in water and common organic solvents. Elem anal. Calcd for C8H12ZnN2S2O4: C, 30.63; H, 3.83; N, 8.93; S, 20.42. Found: C, 30.66; H, 3.78; N, 8.96; S, 20.36.

Synthesis of [Cd(LTP)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

To a solution of Cd(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.067 g, 0.25 mmol) in H2O (4 mL) was added a solution of LTP (0.075 g, 0.56 mmol) in H2O (4 mL) to give a mixed solution. After several days, colorless cubic block crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained by very slow evaporation of the mixed solution. The products were washed with H2O and dried in air (65% yield based on Cd(II)). The as-synthesized material is insoluble in water and common organic solvents. Elem anal. Calcd for C8H12CdN2S2O4: C, 26.64; H, 3.33; N, 6.20; S, 17.76. Found: C, 26.70; H, 3.28; N, 6.20; S, 17.73.

Synthesis of [Ni(LTP)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

A procedure identical with that of 1 was followed to prepare 3, except that Zn(NO3)2·4H2O was replaced by Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.073 g, 0.25 mmol). Green rectangular block crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained. The products were washed with H2O and dried in air (57% yield based on Ni(II)). The as-synthesized material is insoluble in water and common organic solvents. Elem Anal. Calcd for C8H12NiN2S2O4: C, 31.30; H, 3.91; N, 9.13; S, 20.87. Found: C, 31.36; H, 3.97; N, 9.05; S, 20.80.

Synthesis of [Zn(LTP)2] n  (1)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.065 g, 0.25 mmol), LTP (0.075 g, 0.56 mmol), C2H5OH (1 mL), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (2 mL) was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 100 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min. Colorless rectangular block crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained. The products were washed with H2O and dried in air (56% yield based on Zn(II)). The as-synthesized material is insoluble in water and common organic solvents. Elem anal. Calcd for C8H12ZnN2S2O4: C, 30.63; H, 3.83; N, 8.93; S, 20.42. Found: C, 30.66; H, 3.78; N, 8.96; S, 20.36.

Synthesis of [Cd(LTP)2] n  (2)

To a solution of Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (0.067 g, 0.25 mmol) in H2O (4 mL) was added a solution of LTP (0.075 g, 0.56 mmol) in H2O (4 mL) to give a mixed solution. After several days, colorless cubic block crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained by very slow evaporation of the mixed solution. The products were washed with H2O and dried in air (65% yield based on Cd(II)). The as-synthesized material is insoluble in water and common organic solvents. Elem anal. Calcd for C8H12CdN2S2O4: C, 26.64; H, 3.33; N, 6.20; S, 17.76. Found: C, 26.70; H, 3.28; N, 6.20; S, 17.73.

Synthesis of [Ni(LTP)2] n  (3)

A procedure identical with that of 1 was followed to prepare 3, except that Zn(NO3)2⋅4H2O was replaced by Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.073 g, 0.25 mmol). Green rectangular block crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained. The products were washed with H2O and dried in air (57% yield based on Ni(II)). The as-synthesized material is insoluble in water and common organic solvents. Elem Anal. Calcd for C8H12NiN2S2O4: C, 31.30; H, 3.91; N, 9.13; S, 20.87. Found: C, 31.36; H, 3.97; N, 9.05; S, 20.80.

metadata.title: Three Novel Homochiral Helical Metal−Organic Frameworks Based on Amino Acid Ligand: Syntheses, Crystal Structures, and Properties
